questions.text: Using 'h&w' for 'health and wellbeing' is acceptable throughout your exam responses.
questions.explanation: Unexplained abbreviations can lose marks. Write the term in full first, abbreviate it in brackets, then use the abbreviation for the rest of THAT question only.
questions.studyTip: First use: 'health and wellbeing (HWB)'. Then: 'HWB'.

questions.text: Scientific abbreviations like BMI and study design terms like DALY, HALE, WHO, and SDGs can be used without explanation.
questions.explanation: Standard scientific abbreviations and terms from the study design are acceptable. BMI, DALY, HALE, YLL, YLD, WHO, UN, SDGs, PBS—these don't need defining.
questions.studyTip: Study design abbreviations = OK. Made-up shortcuts = not OK.

questions.text: Writing 'this impacts burden of disease' or 'impacts YLL' is a complete answer.
questions.explanation: You must specify the DIRECTION. 'Increasing YLL due to premature death' or 'decreasing HALE'. Simply saying 'impacts' without increase/decrease doesn't demonstrate understanding.
questions.studyTip: Always state: INCREASING or DECREASING. Never just 'impacting'.

questions.text: Impact questions require you to clearly identify whether the effect is an increase or decrease.
questions.explanation: For burden of disease, health status, or human development questions, specify: 'increasing morbidity', 'decreasing life expectancy', 'improving HALE'. Direction matters.
questions.studyTip: Impact = direction. Which way is it going?

questions.text: If a question says 'besides body weight', you can still mention body weight if it's relevant.
questions.explanation: Questions that exclude specific answers mean those answers won't receive marks. 'Besides body weight' or 'other than income' are direct instructions—follow them.
questions.studyTip: Read exclusions carefully. They're not suggestions.

questions.text: When questions specify 'other than' or 'besides', you must avoid those topics entirely.
questions.explanation: Some students lost marks by including excluded content. If it says 'explain two OTHER characteristics', don't repeat one already mentioned.
questions.studyTip: Crossed out in the question = crossed out in your answer.

questions.text: A thorough explanation of a concept is enough, even if you don't link it to the specific context in the question.
questions.explanation: You must answer in the correct context. If Question 3 asks about 'improved health outcomes', your response about lack of food/income doesn't answer that—it's the opposite.
questions.studyTip: Check: am I answering what they ASKED?

questions.text: Answering questions in the wrong context (e.g., discussing lack of food when asked about having food) means losing marks.
questions.explanation: The question about why food is a prerequisite for health needed positive impacts of having food—not negative impacts of lacking it. Context precision matters.
questions.studyTip: Prerequisites FOR health ≠ lack of prerequisites.

concepts.title: Use different examples for linked questions

questions.text: Using the same example of health and wellbeing for multiple parts of a question is efficient.
questions.explanation: If you give the same example for parts a and b, you won't get marks for part b. Plan your examples carefully to avoid repetition across question parts.
questions.studyTip: Different parts = different examples. Plan ahead.

questions.text: Multi-part questions often require different examples for each part to access all marks.
questions.explanation: Question 13 required different examples of mental health and wellbeing for individual and national levels. Using the same example twice meant losing marks in part b.
questions.studyTip: Before writing, plan which example goes where.

questions.text: A 2-mark question and a 6-mark question should have responses of similar length.
questions.explanation: The command term AND mark allocation guide your detail level. A 6-mark extended response needs substantially more depth than a 2-mark identification question.
questions.studyTip: More marks = more detail, more links, more depth.

questions.text: Command terms and mark allocation together indicate how much detail is required.
questions.explanation: 'Identify' with 1 mark needs a brief answer. 'Discuss' with 10 marks needs comprehensive coverage. Scale your response accordingly.
questions.studyTip: Marks are your word-count guide.

questions.text: Listing components of human development is enough when discussing a program's impact on human development.
questions.explanation: Listing components without linking them to the specific program doesn't demonstrate understanding. You must show HOW the program impacts each component.
questions.studyTip: Don't list—link. Show the connection to the specific case.

questions.text: Questions requiring links between concepts need explicit connections, not just descriptions of each concept.
questions.explanation: Students struggled with linking questions (8d, 10d). Show the relationship: 'The program builds disaster resilience, thereby increasing capacity to live longer and healthier lives.'
questions.studyTip: Use linking words: 'thereby', 'which leads to', 'resulting in'.

questions.text: When linking two SDGs, you only need detailed knowledge of one.
questions.explanation: Questions about relationships between SDGs (like SDG 3 and SDG 4) require understanding of BOTH. Many students knew SDG 3 well but couldn't demonstrate understanding of SDG 4.
questions.studyTip: Know the key features of EACH SDG you might need to link.

questions.text: Linking SDG questions require demonstrating understanding of both SDGs involved.
questions.explanation: SDG 4 (Quality Education) links to SDG 3 (Good Health): 'Ensuring literacy means children can read health information, reducing waterborne disease, achieving SDG 3.'
questions.studyTip: SDG links: Feature of SDG A → leads to → Feature of SDG B.

questions.text: Structuring extended responses around Source 1, then Source 2, then Source 3 is an effective approach.
questions.explanation: This approach tends to be disjointed, with responses restating stimulus material and incorporating little student knowledge. Structure around CONCEPTS instead.
questions.studyTip: Structure by concept (e.g., three health approaches), weaving in sources.

questions.text: Higher-scoring extended responses are structured around concepts rather than the stimulus material.
questions.explanation: For the health status question, structure around: old public health, biomedical approach, Ottawa Charter. Incorporate relevant sources into each section.
questions.studyTip: Concepts = your framework. Sources = your evidence.

questions.text: Assessors can tell which source you're using without you identifying it.
questions.explanation: Signpost your sources: 'one in ten children died of diarrhoeal disease (Source 1)'. This helps assessors verify you've used all required sources.
questions.studyTip: Name your source in brackets: '(Source 2)' or '(as shown in Source 1)'.

questions.text: Signposting stimulus material helps assessors identify that all required sources have been used.
questions.explanation: Clear references like 'Melbourne homes being connected to sewerage systems (Source 2)' prove you've engaged with the material systematically.
questions.studyTip: Each source should be explicitly referenced at least once.

questions.text: Discussing health approaches is enough without connecting them to specific health status measures.
questions.explanation: Some students described approaches well but didn't link to health status improvements. You must show HOW each approach improved measures like life expectancy, mortality rates, morbidity.
questions.studyTip: Every approach needs a health status outcome.

questions.text: Extended responses about health status improvements must explicitly link approaches to health status measures.
questions.explanation: Go beyond life expectancy. Use under-5 mortality, maternal mortality, morbidity, prevalence/incidence of specific diseases. Show specific improvements.
questions.studyTip: Approach → action → health status measure improvement.

questions.text: For extended responses, diving straight in ensures you don't run out of time.
questions.explanation: Planning prevents problems. Identify which health status measure you'll discuss with each approach. This averts the issue of discussing approaches without linking to health status.
questions.studyTip: 2 minutes planning saves 5 minutes fixing.

questions.text: Planning your extended response helps ensure you cover all required aspects.
questions.explanation: A quick plan: 'Old public health → under-5 mortality. Biomedical → maternal mortality. Ottawa Charter → NCD prevalence.' Then write coherently.
questions.studyTip: Approach | Link to stimulus | Health status measure. Plan all three.

questions.text: Life expectancy at birth, mean years of schooling, and GNI per capita are the three dimensions of the HDI.
questions.explanation: Those are INDICATORS, not dimensions. The three DIMENSIONS are: a long and healthy life, knowledge, and a decent standard of living. Know the difference.
questions.studyTip: Dimensions = broad categories. Indicators = how we measure them.

questions.text: The HDI dimensions are: a long and healthy life, knowledge, and a decent standard of living.
questions.explanation: Each dimension has indicators: life expectancy (long healthy life), years of schooling (knowledge), GNI per capita (standard of living). Questions may ask for either.
questions.studyTip: Dimension → Indicator: Health → Life expectancy. Knowledge → Schooling.

concepts.title: Understand sexual orientation and gender identity

questions.text: Generic statements about discrimination apply equally well to sexual orientation and gender identity questions.
questions.explanation: Responses must be SPECIFIC to sexual orientation (gay, lesbian, bisexual) or gender identity (transgender). Generic discrimination statements without this specificity don't gain full marks.
questions.studyTip: Name the group specifically: transgender, gay, lesbian.

questions.text: Questions about reducing discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity require specific examples.
questions.explanation: 'Through reducing discrimination, fewer transgender people will be denied employment' is specific. 'Reducing discrimination improves wellbeing' is too generic.
questions.studyTip: Specific group + specific impact = full marks.

concepts.title: Understand SDG objectives vs individual SDGs

questions.text: The objectives of the SDGs are the same as individual SDGs like 'No Poverty' or 'Zero Hunger'.
questions.explanation: The objectives are broader: end extreme poverty, fight inequality and injustice, address climate change. Individual SDGs like 'No Poverty' are specific goals, not the overarching objectives.
questions.studyTip: Objectives = big picture aims. Individual SDGs = specific targets.

questions.text: SDG objectives include: end extreme poverty, fight inequality and injustice, and address climate change.
questions.explanation: Many students confused objectives with specific SDGs or explained why SDGs were developed. Know the three key objectives and what they mean.
questions.studyTip: Three objectives: poverty, inequality, climate. Learn them.

questions.text: Discussing general impacts of climate change is enough for SDG 13 ('Climate Action') questions.
questions.explanation: You must demonstrate understanding of SDG 13's specific features: strengthening resilience, building capacity, integrating climate measures into policy. Climate impacts alone aren't enough.
questions.studyTip: SDG 13 = action to address climate, not just climate impacts.

questions.text: SDG 13 questions require knowledge of specific features like strengthening resilience and integrating climate measures into policies.
questions.explanation: 'Strengthening resilience to climate disasters by building flood walls means schools aren't destroyed, so children can access education.' Link SDG 13 features to outcomes.
questions.studyTip: Know SDG 13 features: resilience, capacity building, policy integration.

questions.text: Tobacco control initiatives relate to the WHO priority 'Protect health — addressing health emergencies'.
questions.explanation: Tobacco control relates to 'Promote health — promoting healthier populations'. This priority focuses on preventing NCDs and promoting mental health. Don't confuse it with health emergencies.
questions.studyTip: Tobacco → NCDs → Promote health. Not Protect health.

questions.text: The WHO priority 'Promote health' focuses on preventing non-communicable diseases and promoting mental health.
questions.explanation: 'One billion more people enjoying better health' includes reducing lung cancer through tobacco control. Match initiatives to the correct WHO priority.
questions.studyTip: Three priorities: Provide (UHC), Protect (emergencies), Promote (NCDs).

questions.text: 'Country to country' or 'government to government' accurately describes bilateral aid.
questions.explanation: Be precise: bilateral aid is from the government of one country TO THE GOVERNMENT of another country. 'Country to country' isn't specific enough about who gives and receives.
questions.studyTip: GOVERNMENT of Country A → GOVERNMENT of Country B.

questions.text: Bilateral aid is given from the government of one country directly to the government of another country.
questions.explanation: The key word is 'government' on BOTH sides. This distinguishes bilateral aid from multilateral aid (through international organisations) or NGO aid.
questions.studyTip: Bilateral = government-to-government. Be specific.

questions.text: The biomedical approach can be accurately described as a 'quick fix' for health problems.
questions.explanation: This is inaccurate. Cancer treatment isn't quick. Chronic disease management isn't quick. Many illnesses can't be cured or 'fixed'. Avoid this oversimplification.
questions.studyTip: Biomedical = diagnose, treat, cure where possible. Not always quick.

questions.text: The biomedical approach involves diagnosis, treatment, and returning individuals to their pre-illness state where possible.
questions.explanation: Focus on the process: medical technology, practitioners, treating and diagnosing diseases. Acknowledge that not all conditions are curable or quickly resolved.
questions.studyTip: Accurate description > catchy but wrong phrases.

questions.text: Human development is simply about improving living standards.
questions.explanation: Human development is broader: creating an environment where people develop to their full potential, lead productive creative lives, participate in decisions, access knowledge, achieve decent living standards.
questions.studyTip: Human development = full potential, not just money.

questions.text: Human development refers to creating an environment where people can develop to their full potential and lead creative, productive lives.
questions.explanation: Key elements: enhancing choices, extending capabilities, access to knowledge and health, decent standard of living, community participation, decision-making involvement.
questions.studyTip: List the components: potential, creativity, participation, choices, capabilities.

questions.text: Higher levels of unemployment is an accurate characteristic of low-income countries.
questions.explanation: This is NOT accurate. Low-income countries often have HIGH employment, but in low-paying jobs like agriculture. The issue is low wages, not unemployment.
questions.studyTip: Low income ≠ high unemployment. It's low-paying work.

questions.text: Low-income countries often have high employment in low-paying sectors like agriculture.
questions.explanation: According to World Bank data, people are employed but earning very little. Focus on wage levels, gender inequality, inadequate housing—not unemployment rates.
questions.studyTip: Employed but poor. That's the characteristic.

questions.text: Any environmental improvement counts as 'Create Supportive Environments' from the Ottawa Charter.
questions.explanation: This action area specifically means creating social environments that are safe and culturally appropriate. Many students couldn't demonstrate this understanding or link it to case studies.
questions.studyTip: Supportive environments = safe, culturally appropriate SOCIAL settings.

questions.text: Create Supportive Environments focuses on social environments that are safe and culturally appropriate.
questions.explanation: It's not just physical environment. Think: safe workplaces, inclusive communities, environments where people feel accepted regardless of background.
questions.studyTip: Social environment focus, not just physical.

questions.text: Stating that fruit contains 'nutrients' or 'vitamins and minerals' is enough for underconsumption questions.
questions.explanation: You must name SPECIFIC nutrients (vitamin C, fibre, potassium) and link them to SPECIFIC diseases. 'Fibre in fruit reduces colorectal cancer risk by regulating bowel movements.'
questions.studyTip: Specific nutrient → specific health outcome.

questions.text: Underconsumption questions require naming specific nutrients and linking them to specific diseases.
questions.explanation: Vitamin C → anaemia, immune function. Fibre → colorectal cancer, satiety. Antioxidants → cancer prevention. Make the connection explicit.
questions.studyTip: Fruit has fibre → fibre prevents constipation → constipation is colorectal cancer risk factor.

questions.text: Describing current economic practices is enough for economic sustainability questions.
questions.explanation: Sustainability REQUIRES reference to current AND future generations. 'Ensuring incomes continue to rise in line with inflation into the future' shows the sustainability element.
questions.studyTip: Sustainability = now AND future. Always mention both.

questions.text: Economic sustainability questions require reference to meeting needs of current and future generations.
questions.explanation: 'Ensuring job creation now and in the future so people can afford essentials' demonstrates sustainability thinking. Without 'future', it's just economics.
questions.studyTip: Add 'now and in the future' to sustainability answers.

questions.text: Writing about impacts OF discrimination answers questions about REDUCING discrimination.
questions.explanation: Some students wrote about how discrimination harms health instead of how REDUCING discrimination promotes health. These are opposite directions—read the question carefully.
questions.studyTip: Reducing discrimination → positive outcome. Not: discrimination → negative outcome.

questions.text: Questions about reducing discrimination require discussing positive outcomes of less discrimination.
questions.explanation: 'Reducing discrimination means fewer transgender people denied employment, enabling them to earn income for nutritious food, promoting physical health.' Positive framing.
questions.studyTip: Frame positively: less discrimination = improved access to...

questions.text: Simply stating 'lobbying' as a social action is a complete answer.
questions.explanation: You must specify: WHO is being lobbied, and ABOUT WHAT. 'Lobbying governments to increase funding for women's education programs' is specific. 'Lobbying' alone isn't.
questions.studyTip: Social action = specific action + specific target + specific issue.

questions.text: Social action examples must include specific details about who, what, and how.
questions.explanation: 'Donating to World Vision to fund education programs for girls in rural communities' has all elements: action (donate), organisation (World Vision), target (girls' education), context (rural).
questions.studyTip: Vague = no marks. Specific = marks.

questions.text: Listing features of effective aid and describing how they appear in a program is a complete answer.
questions.explanation: You must also EVALUATE the benefits of the feature. Many students could list and describe but couldn't explain WHY the feature makes the program more effective.
questions.studyTip: Feature + example + WHY it helps = complete answer.

questions.text: Aid program questions require explaining WHY the feature makes the program more effective.
questions.explanation: 'Partnerships allow resources to be pooled and expertise shared, increasing the chance of a well-rounded, successful program.' This evaluates the benefit, not just describes it.
questions.studyTip: Describe WHAT → Explain WHY it works.

concepts.title: Check which Ottawa Charter action areas apply

questions.text: Any Ottawa Charter action area can be applied to any health program.
questions.explanation: Not all action areas fit all cases. 'Build Healthy Public Policy' wasn't evident in the NSW Knockout case study and wasn't accepted. Match action areas to what's actually shown.
questions.studyTip: Check: is this action area ACTUALLY in the case study?

questions.text: You must demonstrate that your chosen Ottawa Charter action area is actually reflected in the case study.
questions.explanation: 'Develop Personal Skills' and 'Strengthen Community Actions' were easier to link to the Knockout Health Challenge. Students who chose 'Create Supportive Environments' struggled to make connections.
questions.studyTip: Choose the action area that CLEARLY fits the evidence.

questions.text: Low GNI per capita and high poverty rates are acceptable when asked for characteristics OTHER than low income.
questions.explanation: Low GNI and poverty ARE related to low income. If asked for characteristics other than income, use: gender inequality, inadequate housing, environmental factors, lack of clean water.
questions.studyTip: Other than income = avoid money-related characteristics.

questions.text: When excluded from using income or education, focus on environmental, social, or health system characteristics.
questions.explanation: Gender inequality (social), inadequate housing with poor ventilation (environmental), lack of clean water—these are genuinely different characteristics.
questions.studyTip: Think: social, environmental, health system factors.

questions.text: Life expectancy is the main health status measure you need to discuss.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses used diverse measures: under-5 mortality, maternal mortality, morbidity, prevalence and incidence of specific diseases. Life expectancy alone limits your response.
questions.studyTip: Beyond life expectancy: mortality rates, morbidity, disease prevalence.

questions.text: Using multiple health status measures (mortality, morbidity, prevalence, incidence) demonstrates broader understanding.
questions.explanation: Link different approaches to different measures: sewerage → under-5 mortality. Midwives → maternal mortality. Tobacco policy → lung cancer prevalence. Show range.
questions.studyTip: Different intervention = different health status measure.
